author: Bryan Carey, Houston Finance Examiner
title: Kroger issues recall of food seasonings
text:
Kroger issues recall of food seasonings Use your key for the next article Four seasonings are being recalled due to the risk of salmonella contamination. on.aol.com 
Another food poisoning scare has resulted in a nationwide recall for a major retailer, according to a CNN.com story published July 29, 2015. 
Kroger , the grocery store chain headquartered in Cincinnati, Ohio and with large presence across the United States, stated that its seasonings have tested positive for salmonella, prompting the retail giant to issue a full recall. 
In question are four specific seasonings, all of which carry the Kroger brand: Kroger Ground Cinnamon, Kroger Garlic Power, Kroger Bacâ€™n Buds, and Kroger Coarse Ground Black Pepper. Other seasonings are considered safe, at least for now. 
What prompted the recall was a routine Food and Drug Administration test. A sample of Kroger Garlic Powder taken from a store in South Carolina was tested for contaminants and it turned up positive for salmonella. 
Kroger has taken quick action, removing all of these spices from stores. Kroger says there have been no reports of sickness, but it is taking no chances and is asking customers who recently purchased any of the four affected spices to return them to a nearby Kroger store for a refund or, if possible, for replacement product. 
Affected stores include not just Kroger, but other stores that are owned and operated by Kroger such as Ralphs, Food 4 Less, Fred Meyer, Foods Co., Fry's, King Soopers, City Market, Smith's, Jay C, Dillons, Baker's, Gerbes, Ruler Foods, Pay Less, Owen's, and Scott's. The four recalled spices could have been purchased in any of the above stores and if they have, they are subject to the provisions of the recall. 
If customers have specific questions about the recall, they can get answers by calling the Kroger customer support line, 1-800-576-4377. Suggested Links
